awd_titl_txt: Effects of the Engagement, Exploration, Explanation, Elaboration, and Evaluation Instructional Model: Systematic Review and Innovation Through New Meta-Analysis Methodology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by conducting basic research on the effectiveness of a commonly used teaching approach in K-12 STEM education, as well as by providing a tool that can help others do similar research studies.  Specifically, the project will study the effectiveness of the 5E (Engagement, Exploration, Explanation, Elaboration, and Evaluation) model for instruction, which is commonly used in K-12 STEM education to organize instruction within programs, units, and lessons. More than 100 research studies have tested the effects of using the 5E model. However, these published studies differ from one another in content area focus, research methods, and other features. This project will use meta-analysis, a method that can scientifically combine results from many studies even when the studies are not identical.  Through meta-analysis, the project will examine how the 5E model affects students’ STEM achievement, including their subject matter knowledge, critical thinking abilities, and scientific inquiry skills. In addition, this project will create a free, open-source tool that will it easier for other researchers to do meta-analysis. Thus, the project is expected to provide information about how science instruction can be improved and also improve the process of conducting meta-analyses.

This project’s primary focus is to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis of studies that evaluate the effectiveness of the 5E instructional model and interventions based directly on the 5E model on students’ STEM achievement outcomes. This project also will create an open-source, user-friendly data extraction and analysis tool specifically created for researchers conducting meta-analyses. The tool will advance the field by automating the codebook to data system process, applying established relational database techniques for data collection, and creating a simple graphical user interface for state-of-the-art meta-analytical techniques using the R platform. The two project activities will be conducted together, with the meta-analysis informing the creation of the meta-analytic tool, and the tool will be used to conduct the meta-analysis. The meta-analysis results will inform the design of STEM interventions (5E-based or otherwise) that have the goal of increasing STEM literacy and workforce outcomes, and the meta-analytic tool will advance the field of systematic review and meta-analysis methodology by providing applied meta-analysts with an open-source, free tool to streamline the meta-analytic process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project achieved two primary goals: (1) to conduct and publish a comprehensive systematic review and meta-analysis on the effects of 5E-based interventions on students’ STEM achievement, and (2) to produce a user-friendly, collaboration-focused data extraction and analysis tool that applied meta-analysts can use to create high-quality, efficient, and state-of-the-art meta-analyses. 

The systematic review and meta-analysis examined the effects of the 5E (Engage, Explore, Explain, Elaborate, Evaluate) instructional model and the related 3E (which focuses only on Engage, Explore, Explain) and 7E (which adds a prior Elicit and a final Extend step) models. Our meta-analysis is the most comprehensive to date on this topic, including studies that used randomized controlled trials to evaluate the implementation of a 5E or related model in pre-kindergarten through grade 12, in the United States and internationally, from 1990 to 2021. Our results indicated large, positive results for science, math, and motivation outcomes: 5E and related instructional models increased science achievement by 29 percentage points, increased math achievement by 26 percentage points, and increased motivation by 10 percentage points (all expressed in the What Works Clearinghouse improvement index).

We developed the MetaReviewer software to facilitate core activities in conducting meta-analyses, including creating a coding form from a study codebook, systematically coding information from studies, reconciling coding choices from multiple coders, generating effect sizes, and managing project teams. MetaReviewer is freely available at http://www.metareviewer.org. We launched a beta version of the software in fall 2022, and solicited input from beta users to refine the software before its full launch to the public in December 2023. As of December 2024, more than 900 active users were working on nearly 500 meta-analysis projects using MetaReviewer. Users are from more than 135 organizations based in more than 37 U.S. states (plus Washington, D.C.) and 35 countries across 6 continents. User roles include college/university faculty, staff, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers; physicians and medical students; and researchers at for-profit, non-profit, government, and independent organizations.

To disseminate findings from the 5E meta-analysis, we published a journal article in AERA Open and registered our study protocol with the Open Science Framework. We also produced an associated infographic to communicate the findings to broad audiences, and presented the findings at three researcher and practitioner conferences for national and international audiences. In addition, we conducted an evidence gap map analysis and published a brief identifying needs for further research on the effectiveness of 5E and related models.

To increase awareness of MetaReviewer and support its use, we presented the software at four conferences and gave four invited presentations for national and international audiences, and incorporated MetaReviewer into annual meta-analysis training institutes funded by NSF (Award #1937412) and the U.S. Department of Education. We also created and periodically update a 508-accessible User Guide and operate a Help Desk. We produced over two dozen blog posts, instructional videos, and other content, which are posted on MetaReviewer’s Learn page and shared via social media.
